title: How Yieldmo Cut Database Costs and Cloud Dependencies
partialText: Yieldmo, an online advertising platform processing billions of daily ad requests, faced high DynamoDB costs and multicloud latency challenges. By migrating to ScyllaDB’s DynamoDB-compatible API, they achieved multicloud flexibility, cut database costs by roughly 50%, and maintained single-digit millisecond latency, enabling fast, scalable, and reliable ad delivery across regions.

title: How An AI Gmail Summary Agent Saves Me 35 Minutes a Day
partialText: An AI-powered Gmail Summary Agent built with n8n can filter promotions, group emails by category, extract action items, and deliver one clean HTML summary daily. Instead of drowning in threads, you get a focused report in 5–10 minutes. The workflow uses Gmail nodes, an OpenAI model, and simple JavaScript formatting—saving time, reducing stress, and scaling with your business.

title: Modern Best Practices for Web Security Using AI and Automation
partialText: AI and intelligent automation are transforming cybersecurity operations. From SOAR-driven incident response and UEBA anomaly detection to predictive vulnerability scoring, organizations can reduce alert fatigue, shrink MTTR, and shift from reactive defense to proactive protection. Success depends on human-in-the-loop governance, strong data quality, and automated workflows that scale at machine speed.

title: How I'd Design a Data Platform From Scratch in 2026
partialText: A Series B startup hired me to build its data platform from scratch. With 50M events/day and a one-person team, I chose boring, scalable tools: Fivetran, Airbyte, BigQuery, dbt, Dagster Cloud, and Looker. No Kafka. No Spark. Total cost under $3K/month. The focus: operability, trust, semantic consistency, and a clear upgrade path—not overengineering for imaginary scale.

title: GPU Infrastructure Is Becoming an Asset Class — Here's Why Crypto Investors Are Paying Attention
partialText: AI is driving a structural GPU shortage as Big Tech pours $600B into infrastructure. Data center GPU markets are projected to grow 10x by 2032. Unlike crypto mining, GPU yield comes from commercial AI compute demand. Platforms like GPUnex let investors access this via structured packages with daily returns. Higher upside than staking, but with hardware depreciation and utilization risks to watch.

title: Why Faster Cross-Border Payments Still Don’t Work for Businesses
partialText: Payment rails have modernized—faster settlement, richer standards, regulatory KPIs. But inside enterprises, data remains fragmented across banks, ERPs, and spreadsheets. Mid-market firms suffer most, lacking the scale to internalize complexity. The real bottleneck isn’t execution speed; it’s post-trade data usability. Closing the last-mile enterprise data gap is key to turning infrastructure reform into real business transparency.

title: AI is Disrupting Everything: Should You Even Study Computer Science?
partialText: AI is disrupting software and knowledge work faster than past tech revolutions due to its velocity and instant distribution. Job displacement is real, and denial is dangerous. But Computer Science isn’t obsolete—it’s evolving. The edge now lies in architecting AI systems, grounding LLMs, managing context, and evaluating outputs. Don’t fight AI. Master it, move from artisan coder to system architect, and keep building to stay sharp.

title: I scanned 5000 random Jupyter Notebooks from GitHub. Here’s the "Graveyard" of secrets I found.
partialText: Amid the AI gold rush, Jupyter notebooks have become a major security blind spot. A scan of 5,000 public .ipynb files uncovered AWS access keys, OpenAI and Hugging Face tokens, prompt injection payloads, and unsafe pickle deserialization risks. Traditional scanners miss notebook outputs, leaving credentials exposed. The real issue isn’t revoking leaked keys—it’s fixing broken developer hygiene before secrets reach production.

title: The Advertising Model is Coming for AI Agents (And It's Worse Than You Think)
partialText: AI agents face unsustainable economics, making advertising inevitable. But unlike traditional ads, AI placements may be invisible—embedded in recommendations shaped by biased training data, RAG retrieval, or affiliate-weighted tools. As platforms like Perplexity and Google experiment with sponsored AI results, the real risk is trust erosion. Hyper-personalized, undisclosed persuasion could redefine digital advertising—and user autonomy.

title: What is Mutuum Finance (MUTM)?
partialText: Mutuum Finance (MUTM) is a decentralized finance platform designed around real financial activity. Its structure is built on two complementary lending models: Peer-to-Contract (P2C) and Peer-To-Peer (P1P) MUTM is priced at $0.04, with over 19,000 holders.

title: From SSH to GitOps: How Infrastructure Operations Scale
partialText: Infrastructure operations evolved from manual SSH-based server management to automated configuration tools, containerization, and ultimately GitOps. Each stage solved scaling and consistency problems while introducing new complexity. Today, GitOps represents a major shift: using Git as the single source of truth for automated, auditable, and scalable infrastructure management.

title: When Did the Economy Become Our Only Measure of Value?
partialText: Economics has become the only thing that seems to matter. It's not just the subject of social discourse but also its language. We spend time, we value things monetarily, we think of the costs. Economics is the real tower of Babel.

title: Minion: What Happens When an Autonomous Agent has Free Reins for A Week
partialText: Building a security-first autonomous AI agent and letting it run without interference for a week

title: How We Recruited and Vetted Our First 3000+ Service Providers on a Marketplace
partialText: Scaling a marketplace isn’t about demand — it’s about turning supply from manual chaos into a system. We rebuilt our onboarding funnel from scratch, filtered 5,000+ applicants down to 400 reliable providers, and learned how to scale trust without burning margins.

title: GLM-5: from Vibe Coding to Agentic Engineering
partialText: Why today’s AI can “vibe code” but fails at real engineering—and how long-context efficiency plus agentic RL closes the gap.

title: Lorentzian Logic: Visualizing High-Fidelity Graph Hierarchies in Hyperbolic Space
partialText: Explore the visualized hyperbolic partitioning trees of the Cora dataset using LSEnet. Discover how Differentiable Structural Information (DSI) and the Lorentz model identify optimal cluster structures without predefined group numbers (K).

title: Decoding Data: The Technical Secrets of LSEnet Algorithms and Benchmarks
partialText: Dive into the technical implementation of LSEnet, including its Breadth-First Search (BFS) decoding algorithm and its performance against elite baselines like GC-Flow and S3GC across major datasets.

title: Curved Space Geometry: Embedding Trees and Finding Midpoints in Hyperbolic Models
partialText: Discover how trees can be embedded into hyperbolic space with arbitrarily low distortion and explore the mathematical foundations of Frechet means and gyro-midpoints in Riemannian manifolds.

title: RAG: A Data Problem Disguised as AI
partialText: RAG systems fail because of broken data pipelines, not bad models. Poor chunking orphans meaning. Stale indexes serve outdated answers. Missing metadata can't filter irrelevant results. Fix Monday: audit your corpus completeness, rebuild indexes regularly, and measure retrieval recall before blaming the LLM. RAG is search with a generative frontend—treat it like one.

title: Graph Information Theory: The Mathematical Proofs Behind LSEnet and DSI
partialText: Access the comprehensive mathematical proofs for Differentiable Structural Information (DSI). Explore the rigorous validation of equivalence, additivity, and graph clustering bounds that power LSEnet and self-organizing networks.
